instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.CPU_VCORE: What is CPU_VCORE? Power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on(hasgreen light) no liquid damage
threads.message:
Hi,

I received this macbook with not turning on issue.
No liquid damage. The board was pretty dusty. But no sing of liquid damage.
When I press the power button the fan spins up a little bit and that's it. It does not do the on-off loop.

Here are the measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5V
<SIGNAL>RTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3V
32kHz present
Y25010 oscillates

Looks like when I hit the power button every power rails are coming on except: <SIGNAL>CPU_VCORE</SIGNAL>.

Checked <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> and Y2805. Y2805 does not oscillate. I changed both Y2805 and <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.

What could this be?

Thank you.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on(hasgreen light) no liquid damage
threads.message: Did you check RTC signals to PCH??, <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR>, should be about 3V on PCH side... Also could be a short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> line....... Could be <CAPACITOR>C6521</CAPACITOR>, shorted USB port...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on(hasgreen light) no liquid damage
threads.message:
Yes, I checked RTC signals. I forgot to mention it in my first post. No short on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> over 20k ohm.

Edit:
I've also
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.05V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on(hasgreen light) no liquid damage
threads.message: If no liquid I would try BIOS first. Backup the old!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> won't turn on(hasgreen light) no liquid damage
threads.message: Definitely no liquid damage. I tried different BIOS, but same thing. I've two same non-working board here for parts. I also tried those BIOS on this board. Nothing changed.
